Award.AwardTitle: Lowrider: The Where, When, and How of Continental Crustal Underplating
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical description:

This project uses continent-wide mapping of a lower crustal layer with high seismic velocity (termed "7.x layer" based on P velocities greater than 7.0 km/s) to answer fundamental questions about the growth of continental crust: 1. Is mafic underplating more common in Proterozoic than stable Archean crust, as previously postulated? 2. Is it associated with rifting and plume tracks? 3. Does magmatic differentiation within the crust generate a mafic lower crust? 4. Does underplating occur during continental collision? The combination of receiver function mapping of a 'double Moho' across the Transportable Array, joint inversions of receiver functions and ambient noise surface waves, previously collected refraction data, lower crustal xenoliths, and spatial and temporal relationships of 7.x layer extent to tectonic provinces is used to map the 7.x layer across the continental U.S. and relate its presence to the time sequence of continental assembly and subsequent tectonic processes.

Nontechnical explanation / broader significance:

The assembly and growth of the North American continental crust is a sequence of episodes of collisions between continental blocks, crustal thickening and extension, and widespread melting. Continental crust is usually composed of material that has much slower seismic wavespeeds (i.e., the velocity with which earthquake waves travel through the material) than the underlying mantle. However, several of the continent-building processes lead to the formation of a lower crustal layer with higher seismic velocities that lie in between typical mantle and crustal values. This project maps the geographic extent of this high-velocity lower crustal layer using seismic data from the continent-wide EarthScope Transportable Array. The extent of the layer relative to geological provinces mapped on the surface and known areas of continental collision, breakup, and crustal melting provides information on the timing and mechanism of emplacement of the layer. Additional information comes from lower crustal rocks that were transported to the surface during volcanic eruptions and from seismic explosion data that were recorded in the past. EarthScope offers the first opportunity to collate all these data across the entire width of a continent in order to answer fundamental questions about how continental crust is built.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The topmost layer of the solid Earth, referred to as the Earth's crust, consists of a few tens of kilometers made of a less dense average rock composition than the layers underneath. Continental crust is even lighter than oceanic crust, lies mostly above sea level, and comprises the land masses on which humans live. Because of its buoyancy, continental crust is very long-lived, unlike oceanic crust (which sinks back into the Earth's mantle at subduction zones because it is denser). The longevity of continental crust leads to gradual growth of continents. By investigating the structure of the crust, we can look far back into the past to determine how continents were assembled. 

Our particular interest for this study is in a layer between 'normal' continental crust and the mantle that has higher seismic velocities  and higher density than average continental crust. This high-velocity layer is found in some places and not in others. It is proposed to form when mantle melt rises and ponds and crystallizes at the bottom of the crust; when a sliver of crust is shoved sideways beneath another piece of continental crust during collision of continents; or when crust melts partially and lighter components escape upwards, leaving a high-velocity, dense residue behind. By mapping the high-velocity layer across the continental U.S., we can investigate how the continent grew (by fusing smaller areas of continental crust and by growing in thickness) as well as how it avoided splitting apart (several rifts, along which the continent could have broken apart, formed but became inactive).

Our approach was twofold. The EarthScope experiment included a network of seismic stations placed 50 miles apart, with stations being picked up and placed in another location after 2 years of recording time, until the entire contigous U.S. was covered. We looked for a seismic signature of the high-velocity crustal layer at all stations. 

The other approach was to perform laboratory measurements on xenoliths, which are chunks of rock that are broken off from deep layers and flung to the surface during volcanic eruptions. We investigated the compositions of these rocks as well as when and under what conditions they were formed.

The history of lower crustal rocks from Montana showed that Montana's crust grew with repeated episodes of material being added from the mantle over a time span of more than a billion years. Lower crustal rocks brought to the surface in a volcanic field in the Four Corners region suggest that a formerly present high-velocity layer was consumed by absorbing water from the mantle 60 million years ago, resulting in a less dense crust that bobbed to higher surface elevation as a result.

The continent-wide seismic results confirm the findings from rock samples and allow us to extend local rock-based observations across states. We confirmed that processes of continental assembly encourage the formation of high-velocity lower crustal layers, as does widespread volcanism. A surprising finding was that continental rifts do not necessarily show a remaining high-velocity layer, even though they are associated with volcanism. 

The outreach component of this project helped a high school in Estes Park, Colorado build their own school seismometer from scratch, introduced the students to the EarthScope experiment, and helped the science club at the school produce two videos on seismometers and earthquake research.
